item.title: The Boost
item.description:
After last weekâ€™s slump, it was good to escape that trough and ascend new heights this week. Itâ€™s a good reminder of the cyclical nature of things, the natural highs and lows, and how being mindful of those gives you opportunity to change tack â€“ if needs be. Itâ€™s another benefit of weeknoting, being able to package up a period of time and conclude your thoughts on it, draw a line in the sand and move on.

Five Things ThatÂ Happened

More than five things happened

One

We had a GOV.UK away day. It was good to hang out with people Iâ€™ve not worked with before and there were great presentations from others in GDS, most notably from Alistair Duggin, Head of Accessibility. Heâ€™s put together a set of user profiles for disabilities and impairments to use when designing services and products. Itâ€™s a great resource for people across government and anyone else in service design or tech.

He also covered how we can meet the new regulations for public sector websitesâ€™ accessibility, for which the Empathy Lab is hugely effective. Having never used screen readers before or had a visual impairment, it helps you experience the benefits of accessible design on the Web.

We didnâ€™t do any strategic, future-vision stuff though people were expecting that. With a quarterly mission structure, weâ€™re updated on where weâ€™re headed quite regularly, but perhaps people are blind to that. As a PM community weâ€™re doing lots of roadmapping at the moment, so Iâ€™ll plump for that being played back to teams. (Iâ€™d also like to make it open to the public, I just need an affirmative response to an email.)

Two

Each fortnight, the product manager community of GOV.UK gets together to chat strategy, tools of practice, methods, opportunities and more. It helps us all keep aligned with each other and the unit stays abreast of industry developments in product management. This week we explored the Jobs to be Done framework with our User Insights Lead, Imeh Akpan.

Itâ€™s something Iâ€™ve found helpful in the past â€“ especially when trying to work out what product improvements to make when your backlogâ€™s beefy â€“ but with an entire country to create user personas for, Jobs to be Done helps us better empathise with what a user is trying to achieve on www.gov.uk.

Itâ€™ll be exciting to develop this thinking further, especially as we try to fuel the reciprocal relationship between users and government that can happen on the site. Itâ€™ll give us opportunities to develop true innovations in democracy both onâ€“ and offline. Most jobs are triggered in the real world, and weâ€™re thinking more about the end-to-end journey people take.

Three

We did more research into request tracing for the publishing pipeline, and we wrote a blog post about what weâ€™ve done thus far. (Hopefully itâ€™ll be published next week!) But weâ€™ve done a full audit of the tools available, an open standard we can use to reduce switching costs, and worked out how much each tool will cost us as it records HTTP requests across the publishing stack.

QUIZ TIME! How many HTTP requests do applications in the GOV.UK publishing pipeline get each week? Answer: ~109 million.

A boy is taken aback. Much like we were.

Also I caught up with our delivery manager as the first half of the quarter has passed, so weâ€™re looking ahead to the next. They were really complimentary on some of my work, but they also gave me challenges for making improvements â€“ mainly on my outwardly perceived attitude. This sort of criticism is really welcome and Iâ€™m glad they brought it up, as I do have a tendency to be blunt or seem unhappy. But thatâ€™s not fair when youâ€™re leading a team and people rely on you, so Iâ€™ve got to be more mindful of that. After some tough talk, I was shocked but overwhelmingly pleased to be told Iâ€™d been nominated for a bonus!

Two good reality checks in one lunchtime.

Four

Thursday was full of future thinking. Working on backlogs for the platform suite of products, thinking about missions for quarters 3 and 4, and how we can do agency-style work with departments as clients.

Weâ€™re refining our OKR approach to mission work. We set wide objectives for making improvements to the platform, break those down into specific missions to achieve outcomes, and measure the success of those with key results. We also set KPIs against the key results, to measure whether we need to do more or less work on those missions. Itâ€™ll bring more experimentation into our product development, which is really exciting and how other contemporary product organisations work.

But this got me thinking about the long-term strategy for GOV.UK and our place in the Semantic Web. The Voice and SEO missions have edged us closer to that, but Iâ€™ve started thinking about other ways to slice our data warehouse. GOV.UK is one of many records of the history of government in the UK â€“ we need to make it understandable to machines, and build ways for products to be developed on top of its output.

By the way, weâ€™re looking for developers and senior developers â€“ get onboard!

Five

And on Friday I chatted with my line manager about the possibilities of promotion. Iâ€™m working to the levels of competency expected of product managers in our DDaT Framework, but a job needs to be created before I can apply and interview for it. And I shouldnâ€™t assume Iâ€™d be the best candidate, but I do feel ready. Not sure how itâ€™ll go but Iâ€™ve got my fingers crossed!

Also managed to encourage our delivery manager to write about the team culture theyâ€™re fostering, so keep an eye out for that blog. Thinking out loud about their work and blogging was the channel through which I learned about and was attracted to GDS, itâ€™s sad that it has declined. But hopefully we can cause a ripple of new, more frequent writing to ebb out of our teamsâ€™ work.

Reflections

  • This is for everyone, always
  • User journeys are too flat, what they need is context
  • No man is an island
  • The future is exciting â€“ and itâ€™s an honour to nerd out about the Web and have fun at work!

What Iâ€™mÂ Cooking

  • Grilled peach salad with mozzarella, pomegranate molasses & balsamic dressing and Parma ham
  • Hot Punjabi prawn curry
  • Masala chicken breast with pea shoot salad, spiced quinoa and carrot & coriander salad

What Iâ€™mÂ Reading

  • Teams from Scratch â€“ Part 1: Psychological Safety
  • Solid: Empowering people through choice
  • How long will the UK stay the world leader in opendata?
  • The Threat of Hylomorphic Design Thinking

item.title: The Farewell
item.description:
This week I was all over the shop mentally. On Friday I had to just bed down in work with headphones on, but all-in-all itâ€™s been another good week. We lost a good member of the team, but the weeknotes community has proven itself incredible yet again. Happy to say that we even managed to attract someone new to the crew!

Four Things ThatÂ Happened

More than four things happened

One

Monday and Tuesday were filled with the introduction and basic training days for user research for government services. Though Iâ€™m no stranger to the practice (and have written about what happens when you donâ€™t do user research), I wanted to see if the context of working in government changed anything.

It turns out it doesnâ€™t, not by much. User research is such a robust, worthy field of work that you will reap the rewards by taking time to listen to what people need. The core concept is to reduce wasted effort and time by building the right thing, what people need not what they want. The only difference with user research in government is that you canâ€™t be selective with your user personas: this is for everyone. In the private sector your personas focus around people whoâ€™ll drive your revenue, but not so in government.

My only criticism of the course is that I donâ€™t feel enough time was spent on eliminating bias. During the activities and practice sessions, the research questions were tainted by bias â€“ designed to validate assumptions rather than invalidate, leading one to an expected answer â€“ and user stories ended up being solutionistic. Itâ€™s no fault of the course leaders, they had lots to cover for an audience relatively new to a complex field, but Iâ€™ll pass on the feedback. Bias is one of the more difficult topics, but this article on cognitive biases that affect decisions is gold-dust.

Someone also told the story of how theyâ€™d seen several teams conduct research after delivering a project, as a checkbox exercise to get past the Service Standard. Itâ€™s appalling behaviour and will come back to bite them, as it did me.

Two

Having read how Iâ€™d been wrangling with someone unfamiliar to how we do things at GDS, Ellie offered some advice over lunch. It was really on-the-money and will help me adapt to this personâ€™s way of thinking. What I really need to do is sell the benefits of our approach to working, but itâ€™s unfair to do that without hearing theirs and their motivations for joining GDS.

We also spoke about how the organisation is changing, what that means for product management, and the importance of communicating to stakeholders that some times they donâ€™t know best. Ellieâ€™s really talented and Iâ€™m glad she was able to spend some time helping me, so I must offer to give some back. And it just went to prove how supportive the weeknotes community can be â€“ she even gave me a weeknotes sticker! Thanks, Ellie ðŸ˜Š

Three

We said goodbye to Paul B. His knowledge of our stack is inimitable, but he did an incredible job of passing that on â€“ and rewriting heaps of the dev docs. Weâ€™re going to really miss him, he was a stalwart of the tech community.

Four

We had an excellent check-in with the programme team. Theyâ€™re pleased with the teamâ€™s work, but most amazingly theyâ€™re open to us descoping some of our objectives. Thatâ€™s thanks to my colleague, Martin, whoâ€™s taken the time to see whatâ€™s achievable, whatâ€™s needed, and broken it down into a good strategy. Thereâ€™s a lot going on there, so I hope he wonâ€™t mind passing the reins over to me, Iâ€™m happy to pick up more work. (He did it for during GDPR, which was well needed.)

And despite a few worries about team health previously, right now itâ€™s really good. The team are engaged with their work, they really care about it, and theyâ€™re asking all the right questions during planning. This is no doubt due to our fabulous delivery manager (whom I wonâ€™t name as theyâ€™re not on social media) who has made it their mission to create space us to think, ensure everyoneâ€™s priorities are accounted for, and injects vivacity and enthusiasm into our daily lives (to boot!).

Working with them both these past few months has been a treat and the sort of training you donâ€™t get most places. Iâ€™m intrigued to know which principles drive their work, the maxims they call on to move through the day. They could help me as I progress, Iâ€™m sure.

Reflections

  • Government transformation is a massive undertaking with many minds to help adapt to new ways of working
  • Weâ€™re really privileged in GOV.UK to have been on the frontline of transformation
  • The weeknotes crewdem is ðŸ‘Œ
  • Multidisciplinary working is a treat when it works well
  • Be careful of hubris: communicating your pride to others is an exercise in humility

What Iâ€™mÂ Cooking

  • Kedgeree with smoked haddock and watercress
  • Asparagus, sweet pea and burrata frittata (should have added basil oil to the pea shoot salad)
  • Globe courgette stuffed with spicy rice

What Iâ€™mÂ Reading

  • The 7 Deadly Sins of User Research
  • The Bullshit Web
  • Introducing Data Transfer Project: an open source platform promoting universal data portability
  • Thinking about SLOs

item.title: The Step Up
item.description:
Surprised myself this week by how much I handled it all. Everything feels like itâ€™s fitting together well, and despite one minor wobbler I held it together. But most importantly, thereâ€™s a sense weâ€™re making actual progress.

Despite being skint, I bought tickets to MozFest 2018 to find out where the Web is heading. 13-year-old Steve would be very proud.

Five Things ThatÂ Happened

One

My return flight from Venice on Sunday was delayed by several hours, meaning I didnâ€™t get in to bed until 3.30 a.m. Took the morning off and rolled in at lunch time. Completely failed to clear my inbox except for a few unimportant messages, but I did manage to catch up on the previous weekâ€™s events.

Unrelated to but alongside a pretty major announcement, I was told about our deteriorating team health â€“ both work-induced and general illness. We also talked about how to share good practice or stories of failure in the team, which got us thinking about team culture and leadership from within. Iâ€™ve always been a fan of CharlieHRâ€™s CultureLab and wondered how we might set up our own. If you have any interesting stories from the tech world, dear reader, please do share tales and links with me. First weâ€™ll tinker with retros, and Iâ€™d like to encourage more blogging.

The day ended well, though, with a huddle on the pipeline work. It turns out the team had engaged with the discovery well, but we werenâ€™t out of the trenches yet. We met to look at options, pick over them, and it raised questions about whether our work would be for short-term gains or long-term scalability.

But itâ€™s something Iâ€™ll need to ponder tomorrow on a better nightâ€™s rest.

Two

A packed Tuesday, a standard for my working week, wherein I failed to reach Inbox Zero again. Tons of meetings happened, and I had to prepare slides for our Show & Tell during lunch, which meant I was pretty pooped when it got to pre-planning. But thereâ€™s a much better sense of where weâ€™re headed now: we got used to the ebbs and flows of working on a stretched WebOps team last quarter, and planning is less worrisome.

Another boon is having a workstream to call our own. I presented the discovery-esque work weâ€™d done so far at the Show & Tell, which seemed to go down well. There were murmurs of support from the tech community, its lead architect especially, DataOps, and the team making improvements to the publisher experience were receptive to our creative thinking.

Iâ€™d love for the team to get some feelings of achievement out of the pipeline work this quarter, to be able to say theyâ€™ve made serious improvements to the beating heart of GOV.UK, but Iâ€™m reticent to push too hard â€“ and we need to consider the long-term effects and scalability of our solutions. Itâ€™s going to need some tact, foresight and comfort with having tough conversations. But first weâ€™ll research all the options on the table. (A good nightâ€™s sleep helped after all, and this album by jazz/hip-hop/dub keyboardist & SE Londoner Joe Armon-Jones is a bonus.)

Three

Wednesday was a day of highlights.

  • Inbox Zero! ðŸŽ‰
  • A good planning session with the full team! ðŸ‘Œ
  • A progressive retro! ðŸ†™
  • Team health is good! ðŸ˜
  • I ran a retro for the first time, and people were engaged! ðŸ˜Š
  • People sympathise with how much effort our work takes! ðŸ˜Ž At least enough to retweet/like this a bunch of times anyway!

It was lovely to bump into Emily at the end of the day and talk #weeknotes, how cathartic the practice can be, and the importance of reflection in a job that moves a million miles an hour. Her prose is much classier than mine, so have a gander.

Four

And Thursday wasnâ€™t too bad either. We had some wise words from Neil to kick off the day.

Chatting to Elliot about the work heâ€™d done on request tracing a couple of years ago was really beneficial. Heâ€™d actually got quite far into implementing something useful, but priorities changed and the work was dropped. Later on we searched through our wiki, looked at archived Trello boards, and dredged up old gists and PRs â€“ we found all his work, which means we can pick it up again next sprint.

Weâ€™ll hit the ground running on the pipeline work, starting from where he left off, heading towards our renewed priorities. I must make sure to record all the thinking and doing from this work, in case someone else needs to run with it in the future.

Five

On the whole, Friday was good apart from one hour meeting with a stakeholder. Theyâ€™re relatively new to the organisation but, from what I can tell, also oblivious to government design principles, user research, and any notion that we build with qual/quant data â€“ based on real need â€“ not just whims and fancies. We do not use our time and the public purse to make ineffectual gains. We use research and data to improve a live product, not bias.

Wrangling this person is incredibly stressful â€“ even a fellow senior PM was finding it hard â€“ and I had to take a tea break to chill afterwards.

But that was the silver lining. Wont to get stressed, forgetting to take a step back at times, I took a few moments to decompress and move on. And the rest of the afternoon sailed by with jollity and ease. We even got a shout-out on the programme weeknote, which capped off what was, on the whole, one of my best weeks yet.

Reflections

  • You are a human being, not a human doing.
  • Pebbledash presentations lightly with humour â€“ it makes it easier.
  • Even â€˜boringâ€™ work needs good PR. Be an ambassador for your team.
  • Knowledge management is a good thing, but I donâ€™t yet do enough.
  • Take a step back before you fall into the maelstrom.

What Iâ€™mÂ Cooking

  • Fabada asturiana (white beans, chorizo & black pudding stew)
  • Pornstar purÃ©e (a home-made rip-off of Bomba! XXX)
  • Sonic the Hedgehog chili dogs

Though Iâ€™ve always meant to journal my cooking, I never got around to it and itâ€™s ended up here. Some times Iâ€™ll cook nice things, other times itâ€™ll just be comfort classics (which I wonâ€™t record unless theyâ€™re exciting). But if you ever want a recipe for these, ping me â€“ and prod me if I forget to send one over.

What Iâ€™mÂ Reading

  • Positioning Is the Part of â€œProduct Market Fitâ€ Youâ€™re Likely Ignoring

item.title: The Discovery
item.description:
These weeknotes come to you belatedly, as I was on holiday on Friday and spent the weekend celebrating my 30th with friends. Itâ€™s still a great practice though, helping me tie up the week and reflect on what happened. Makes me wish Iâ€™d been doing it earlier, thereâ€™s so much from building eCasework I could have shared. Thank you to the weeknotes folks for your kind words and encouragement!

Four Things ThatÂ Happened

One

What started out as a packed day ended up being free; meetings moved around giving me time to think. Itâ€™s important to have that time to process things, to actually do the work of a PM.

In the afternoon we had an incident review â€“ a meeting covering the causes and solutions of a technical incident â€“ which has given us more reason to work on the publishing pipeline this quarter. As mentioned in my last weeknote, Iâ€™m keen we take on that work, and the consensus in the room was that we needed it now. With a major national event on the horizon, ensuring the pipeline can reliably deliver content is key.

Thereâ€™s varying levels of experience in the team and Iâ€™d been planning on holding a mapping session followed by some problem sorting. After that we could implement some request tracking to measure the pipeline, to find out where the bottlenecks were, and then jump into making changes. Tech leads and senior devs thought that my approach was sound and that we needed to build collective understanding â€“ it was comforting to hear my thinking validated, in some part. Many in the team know how to tweak things to fix them, but donâ€™t know why to tweak those things or by how much.

Two

Andy Dudfield, Service Owner at ONS Digital, popped in to chat to the GOV.UK product manager community about the ONS website and how it had been transformed over the last couple of years. Iâ€™d originally invited him in to hear about all the work theyâ€™d been doing on data, to help us think about data.gov.uk, but there were lots of questions from the community about the general website too. It was super pleasing that everyone was so engaged, there was lots of food for thought on the next steps for GOV.UK.

Andyâ€™s presentation and the work at ONS Digital â€“ kicked off by @jukesieâ€™s work, which Andy was keen to point out â€“ gave the PMs corroboration on our thoughts about user personas, DataOps, SEO, the definition of the term open data, and how to engage generalist audiences.

After that we chatted about the campaigns platform and how ONS might use it for the upcoming census. Itâ€™ll be good to have their needs shape the product alongside upcoming EU Exit work, to help avoid feature-bloat and keep the platformâ€™s utility more general.

Three

Thinking about how we define a productâ€™s success in the public sector can be tough. Programmes and transformation are designed to effect change, but a digital product is propelled by metrics. A Product for Good meetup on defining metrics for social impact provided great insight from the tech for good community.

How can you turn qualitative comments into something you can measure quantitatively?

Matt Kepple from Makerble has done lots of thinking on scaling impact measurement and trying to measure in the short term, where indicators are more attributable to your efforts. He said that changing what people do, think or have are the three types of impact story or behavioural change that you can influence. It touched on thoughts Iâ€™d been having back in February and raised in our 52 Weeks of UX lean coffee about measuring emotional impact. Iâ€™ll be able to develop that blog post more now.

Four

On Thursday we set aside two hours to map out the publishing pipeline and its problem space. It was my first time leading a discovery-esque approach to a live â€˜productâ€™ (arguably the platform is an assembly of products), but it went well. Our experienced developers shared knowledge amongst the team, gaps were filled in by others, and the new team members brought new ideas to the table. Following on from a tech intro the previous week, I was able to qualify my understanding of how it all fits together, which was pleasing.

After that we had a discussion on what problems weâ€™d been facing and why, and the conclusion was that we canâ€™t say for certain: we need good metrics to help expose where the bottlenecks lie. Though I had been directing conversation that way to a degree â€“ the Build-Measure-Learn loop is central to hypothesis-driven development â€“ it was great that Paul, previously the programmeâ€™s tech lead, called for this. Weâ€™ll also be able to take a look at work Elliot had done a couple of years back on request tracking, which will not only inform us but could help rebuild trust in the publisher community. â€˜Getting two birds stoned at once,â€™ as Ricky says.

Excited to see how conversations have developed when I get back from holiday next week.

Reflections

  • Stop making new things. Start making old things work.
  • Reach out and meet people. We have a great community in gov.
  • Thereâ€™s other communities you can learn from too!
  • Oh heck, I love this job.

What Iâ€™mÂ Reading

  • Putting users first is not the answer to everything
  • Ten Reasons Not to Measure Impact â€“ and What to Do Instead
  • Why you need â€œneverâ€ in your product roadmap
  • 5 things Nathan Barley taught us about Service Design

What Iâ€™mÂ Cooking

Should have made notes of these, I canâ€™t remember everything we made. To those of you who asked for the aubergine recipe, Iâ€™ll put something together (though it was technically made by my gf!)

  • Texas BBQ chicken with chargrilled sweetcorn rice salad
  • Marinated garlic courgetti with Dijon mustard dressing and rocquefort

item.title: The Reshuffle
item.description:
Reading peopleâ€™s weeknotes was one of the main inspirations for me to join the Civil Service. It sounded like an exciting world, and on my first day at GDS I wrote some notes. I just never got around to publishing themâ€¦and I didnâ€™t carry on writing notes. But when Jonathan joined our team a few weeks ago, he encouraged me to give it another go, so here I am.

If youâ€™d like to learn more about weeknotes, check out this explainer from Sam.

Five Things ThatÂ Happened

One

We kicked off quarter two with a relatively unchanged team and a refreshed enthusiasm for the coming three months. I combed through our backlog to reprioritise cards and clear some clutter. It was a good start and needs more work, itâ€™s important we manage the teamâ€™s scope this quarter. Context-switching is not healthy.

Mondayâ€™s news gave us some good perspective on the epics would could take on this quarter. Having already plumped for one option but been met with uncertainty, a later incident review gave us a good steer â€“ and straight after that, another change to the machinery of government helped us reshuffle our priorities. Thereâ€™s clear value for us to bring which aids stakeholders and end users, whilst building our knowledge of the platform.

Two

Though my job title only says â€˜associate product managerâ€™, Iâ€™m leading the product thinking on a few workstreams this quarter. To make me a better leader, Iâ€™ve set myself some challenges.

  • Be approachable but not constantly interruptible
  • Speak more slowly, and think with purpose
  • Help people spot opportunities

Three

General Assembly, where I did the product management course in 2016, have taken me on as a teaching assistant! ðŸ™Œ This is really exciting for a number of reasons. The TA on my course was helpful in explaining points which the class didnâ€™t fully understand, and he brought a lot of experience to the table. Our tutor was running his own startup but the TA worked Product in a bank, and it was beneficial to hear stories from that perspective. Canâ€™t wait to share my experiences from Porism and GDS.

Mainly Iâ€™m grateful to have a little refresher on their current curriculum. Itâ€™s always iterating based on the nature of this ever-evolving practice, and Iâ€™m keen to see how they see the role developing.

Four

Had some good 1-on-1s with the more seasoned members of the team. Kim Scott says that â€˜the hardest part of building trust is inviting people to challenge youâ€™, but given my relative greenness on the programme, I asked them to provide critical challenge when they felt it necessary.

No one person knows the perfect path for achieving our goals. Itâ€™s why we have a retrospective, to reflect on what happened and how to improve next time.

Five

Weâ€™ve started planning our major proactive health epic for the quarter. Since thereâ€™s a range of experiences on the team and the problem space isnâ€™t super clear, Iâ€™m kicking things off with a discovery to build our knowledge of how applications tie together. Weâ€™ll then map out the problem space for the health epic, allowing us to start validating (or invalidating) our riskiest assumptions and making improvements to the behemoth that is GOV.UK.

This is really invigorating as our team can be seen as having a support or WebOps role, when really we own a product that is the beating heart of the website. Weâ€™ll be viewing the work through the lens of exiting the EU, when responsiveness will be key to communicating changes to the nation effectively. And though no one jumps at the chance to record metrics, taking a lean approach to product improvement is essential to ensure youâ€™re working on the right things. Build, measure, learn.

Oh, and someone asked me to make a presentation about the history of the Web and how it works (for non-techies) ðŸ˜

Reflections

  1. It was good to take stock and reflect on what we actually do at GOV.UK, what our purpose is
  2. Itâ€™s my job to create more joy and less misery in the team
  3. Youâ€™re never done learning
  4. Humanity is essential to building the so-called soft skills of product management
  5. Evangelism is inspiring and helps propagate trust

What Iâ€™mÂ Reading

  • The Cognition Crisis
  • Making the Shift to Platform Product Management
  • Revenge of the PMO
  • So you want to do more facilitation? â€“ (big thank you for the tip on the Post-itÂ® Plus app!)
  • The principles that make me a better product manager

What Iâ€™mÂ Cooking

  • Smoked herring, Dijon mustard and dill pasta salad
  • Courgette and chilli spaghetti â€“ from homegrown courges!
  • Oven-roasted aubergines with sun-dried tomatoes and cheeeeeeese
